body.note: Tune, “Jem of Aberdeen.”22 In D. Sime, ed., The Edinburgh Musical Miscellany (Edinburgh etc.: for W. Gordon et al., 1792), pp. 303-304. Words only in The Goldfinch, or New Modern Songster (1782 etc.), Jem of Aberdeen’s Garland (1785). The air was first published in 1790. WorldCat attributes it to James Hook (1746-1827), for half a century the keyboard artist for the Vauxhall Gardens, one of the first performers in England to use the pianoforte for a concerto, and composer of over 2000 songs, including music for over thirty stage works for Drury Lane and Covent Garden theatres (ODNB).

lg.l: The summer morn was rising sweet,
And odours breath’d on ev’ry gale;
When on the green I chanc’d to meet
With lovely Nancy of the dale.
As when o’er eastern hills the sun
Brings home the new-born may;
So look’d the charming village maid,
As beautiful and gay.
O! have you seen the dew-wet rose,
The vi’let blue, and lily pale?
These flow’rs their blended sweets disclose
In lovely Nancy of the dale.
With downcast look, and many a blush
I fault’ring told my tender tale,
While underneath a may-blown bush
I sat with Nancy of the dale.
Would smiling love attend my pray’r,
And bid my simple arts prevail;
I’d soon possess that charming fair,
The lovely Nancy of the dale.
